title: AB 1673
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 16520 of the Penal Code is amended to define a "firearm" as a device designed for weapon use that expels a projectile through a barrel by explosion or combustion. This definition includes the frame or receiver of the weapon in various sections of the code. The Penal Code includes various sections (26600 to 31830) related to firearms, as well as specific sections (8100, 8101, 8103) of the Welfare and Institutions Code. The definition of "firearm" also encompasses rocket launchers and similar explosive devices. The Penal Code contains sections related to firearms, including specific provisions that exclude unloaded antique firearms from the definition of a "firearm." These provisions are listed in Sections 16750, 16840(b), 25400, 25850-26025, 26030(a)-(c), and 26035-26055. Additionally, certain sections such as 16730(a)(c), 16550, 16960, 17310, 26350-26400, 26500-26588, 26700-26915, 27510, 27530, 27540, and 27545 also exclude unloaded antique firearms. The Penal Code includes sections related to firearms, with specific provisions excluding certain firearms from the definition. For example, Sections 26500 to 26588, 26700 to 26915, 27510, 27530, 27540, and 27545 are listed, along with definitions for "firearm" in various contexts. The Penal Code defines "frame" and "receiver" as parts of a firearm housing the firing mechanism and barrel. These parts can be blanks, castings, or machined bodies designed for further modification to function as a weapon. Section 16520 of the Penal Code is amended to define a "firearm" as a device designed for use as a weapon that expels a projectile through a barrel using explosion or combustion force. The definition includes the frame or receiver of the weapon in various sections of the code. Sections 26500 to 29905, 30150 to 30165, 31615, 31705 to 31830, 34355 to 34370, and 8100, 8101, 8103 of the Welfare and Institutions Code are included in the legislation. In addition to the sections mentioned in the previous legislation, the definition of "firearm" also includes rocket launchers and similar devices with explosive materials, but excludes unloaded antique firearms. The definition of "firearm" excludes unloaded antique firearms in various sections of the legislation, including Sections 26030, 26035 to 26055, 16730, 16550, 16960, 17310, 25250, 26350, 26400, 26500 to 26588, 26700 to 26915, 27510, 27530, 27540, 27545, 27555 to 27585, and 29010 to 29150. In Sections 27510, 27530, 27540, 27545, and 27555 to 27585, the definition of "firearm" is specified. Additionally, in Sections 29010 to 29150, "firearm" includes unfinished frames or receivers that can be easily converted to a finished state. The definition of "frame" and "receiver" in this section refers to the part of a firearm that houses the firing mechanism and can be further machined to be used as part of a functional weapon. Section 16520 of the Penal Code is amended to define a "firearm" as a device designed for weapon use that expels a projectile through a barrel using combustion. This definition includes the frame or receiver of the weapon in various sections of the code. The Penal Code includes various sections that define and regulate firearms, including rocket launchers and similar devices with explosive materials. The Penal Code contains sections that define and regulate firearms, including exemptions for unloaded antique firearms in specific provisions. The Penal Code contains sections that define and regulate firearms, including exemptions for unloaded antique firearms in specific provisions. Sections 26500 to 29150 outline various regulations regarding firearms, including definitions and inclusions of certain types of firearms. The Penal Code regulates firearms, including definitions for "frame" and "receiver" as parts of a firearm. These parts house the firing mechanism and require further machining to be functional. Section 16520 of the Penal Code is amended to define a "firearm" as a device designed for weapon use that expels a projectile through a barrel by explosion or combustion. This definition includes the frame or receiver of the weapon in various sections of the code. Sections 26500 to 31830 of the Penal Code, along with specific sections from the Welfare and Institutions Code, cover various regulations related to firearms and weapons. In addition to regulations in the Penal Code, specific sections from the Welfare and Institutions Code also define "firearm" to include certain devices containing explosive materials, but exclude unloaded antique firearms. The following provisions specify that "firearm" does not include an unloaded antique firearm: Sections 26030, 26035 to 26055, 16730, 16550, 16960, 17310, Division 4.5, Chapter 6, Chapter 7, Sections 26500 to 26588, Sections 26700 to 26915, 27510, 27530, 27540, 27545, Sections 27555 to 27585, and Sections 29010 to 29150. In Sections 29010 to 29150, "firearm" includes the unfinished frame or receiver of a weapon that can be readily converted to a finished frame or receiver. The term "frame" and "receiver" in this section refer to the part of a firearm that houses the firing mechanism and can be easily converted to a functional weapon. Section 1.1 of the bill includes amendments to Section 16520 of the Penal Code, contingent on the enactment of Senate Bill 894 and specific conditions being met by January 1, 2017. Section 1.2 of the bill incorporates amendments to Section 16520 of the Penal Code proposed by this bill, Senate Bill 1407, and Assembly Bill 857, with specific conditions for enactment by January 1, 2017. Section 1.3 of the bill includes amendments to Section 16520 of the Penal Code from Senate Bill 894, Senate Bill 1407, and Assembly Bill 857, with conditions for enactment by January 1, 2017. No reimbursement is required by this act under the California Constitution as it pertains to creating, eliminating, or changing penalties for crimes or infractions.
